We think there are three paths available: bilateral escalation,
negotiation between the two parties, and the U.S. seeking international allies to put pressure on China.

Flaneur Was politics always this dumb? Perhaps we're just getting more cleverer?
BE11:08am

So ..... option one.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

In this scenario, the U.S. imposes additional trade sanctions on China. If Trump actually believes that China’s bilateral
trade surplus with the U.S. is exploitable (that winning a trade war will be “easy”), then escalation is likely.
This approach is obviously the biggest risk to markets. The tariffs announced so far will have only a limited direct
impact on growth, but they pose considerable risk to profits and employment in some sectors. Escalation would
broaden those risks.

BE11:08am

(@Flaneur: I'm not.)

red most imp is how mkt finishes not starts to trade blows. as usual they wheeled out bullard to put a bottom in mkt, no pun intended.
BE11:09am

Option two.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Trump threatened to withdraw from NAFTA, then entered negotiations. He imposed blanket steel and aluminum
tariffs, then provided exemptions for (some) allies. He has managed what he considers a win in renegotiating a
bilateral trade deal with South Korea. He threatened North Korea (and by extension, large parts of South Korea) with
annihilation before surprising his own advisors with a proposal for a bilateral summit meeting. In every case, a
bombastic beginning led to compromise.
If that pattern holds, there will soon be an offer of negotiations with China. China has already asked for such talks.
Xi Jinping’s top economic advisor, Liu He, asked for a list of U.S. trade requests last month in an attempt to head off
yesterday’s trade actions.
Early indications that the two sides may be headed for negotiations have resulted in a renewed bid for risky assets.
Confirmation that the U.S and China will negotiate their differences would add fuel to the bid.

RAVER @Ref! Think FGTH wrote two tribes?
BE11:10am

And option three ....

BE11:10am

The European Union is also unhappy with China’s treatment of intellectual property. If the U.S. and EU joined forces,
leverage on China could be increased. White the Trump administration seems to take a dim view of joint action in
many cases, White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow has already suggested a “coalition of the willing” to deal
with China’s intellectual property practices. The U.S. is apparently looking for allies in its trade dispute with China.
The main problem with this approach is that the EU may be reluctant to cooperate with the U.S. on any basis which
would appeal to Trump. His disregard for formal trade mechanisms has not been well-received in European capitols,
and Europeans’ preference for those mechanisms is likely to try Trump’s patience.

BE11:23am

In West End stock, East End price from 26 July 2017 we argued that today’s share price doesn’t appropriately value JM’s growth projects. For a company with a long track-record of investing productively at a high incremental ROIC this strikes us as clearly anomalous. Back then we argued that JM either needed to do a better job articulating this growth strategy or should accelerate the realization of any hidden value through disposals. If neither comes to bear we speculated that JM would leave itself susceptible to interest from either an activist investor or a potential suitor. JM is trading on near-trough P/E multiples (13x 2020) yet its free cash flow yield of 4% isn’t close to distressed levels. To reconcile the two we need to acknowledge that JM invests roughly twice its D&A into capex. If we strip out this growth component and the associated R&D the free cash flow yield is almost double-digits. Since the VW diesel scandal in 2015 the market has taken a notably pessimistic view on JM’s ability to create value from growth investments. For example, the lack of visibility and long lead times in developing pharmaceutical APIs means investors are understandably reticent to discount too much value. The same can be said for its novel cathode material, eLNO. This is the primary paradox at JM: the company is paying for growth but receiving little credit for it. To that end taking steps to help realise this value or divide the company into ‘high-growth’ and ‘low-growth’ components has some merit.

Retail stocks follow earnings, and growth companies have
outperformed cyclicals in 11 out of the last 15 years. Even with high valuation
multiples we have a clear structural preference for online and global growth
retailers. Long term value is created at those companies that invest in sustainable
growth rather than chase near term profits. These stocks dominate our most
preferred list.

as the rate of share gain by online is accelerating even as the absolute penetration
increases. Undifferentiated retailers are increasingly under pressure from the
negative impact of in-store cannibalisation and consequent P&L deleverage.
Disappointingly, those companies with the largest structural issues are also most
incentivised on short term profits. We can't see a route to long term re-rating.

BE11:44am

Since becoming Fed chair, Jay Powell has argued that, while there may be risks
that the economy overheats down the road, modest wage growth suggests that
the labor market is not currently overheating. This sentiment has been echoed
by several other Fed officials and has allowed the central Fed narrative to remain
that a “gradual” pace of rate hikes remains appropriate, at least for the time
being. In this respect, market participants will pay close attention to average
hourly earnings (AHEs) in Friday’s report. We expect wage growth to tick up
slightly (0.3% forecast vs. 0.2% previous). Our AHEs models, which are based
on the underlying trend in wage growth and a few statistical quirks that have
proven useful for predicting month-on-month fluctuations, point to a print around
0.28%. In addition, if harsh weather affects the report, it is likely to boost AHEs,
as lower wage workers are more likely to be impacted. Should AHEs come in as
we anticipate, the year-over-year rate will rise by about 13 basis points (bps) to
2.74%, still about 3bps shy of January’s recent high point of 2.77%. Such a print
would not materially alter the prevailing Fed view about the labor market.

BE11:45am

Beyond wages, with some incipient concerns that global growth momentum is
slowing, nonfarm payroll gains should take on added importance for the market
this month. After a robust gain of 313k jobs in February, the strongest print
since July 2016, we expect a modest deceleration for headline (+200k forecast)
and private (+200k vs. 287k) nonfarm payrolls, though to a still solid pace. A
continuation of solid job gains, and the income growth that should come with it,
is one reason that we expect the likely Q1 slowdown in consumer spending to be
short-lived. However, March has been a tricky month for employment forecasters
in recent years, as the median consensus estimate has overestimated the initial
March nonfarm payrolls print in four of the last five years by an average of 62k. On
the other hand, recent job gains have exceeded forecaster expectations, as the
consensus has underestimated nonfarm payrolls by an average of 66k over the
past two months. Indeed, while mild February weather likely boosted construction
hiring, which was up 61k in February—the largest one month gain since March
2007 (80k), four Nor’easter storms battering the eastern seaboard over the past
several weeks could portend some payback from this sector.

red fwiw powell also speaking late afternoon
11:45 am
BE11:45am

That said, if our forecast proves close to the mark, this should still serve to push
the unemployment rate (4.0% forecast vs. 4.1% previous) down to a level last
seen in 2000, particularly if last month’s three-tenths uptick in the participation
rate partially reverses. There is a risk that the unemployment rate falls more
sharply, breaking through 4%, if the rise in the participation rate fully reverses.
Indeed, since 2010, the unemployment rate has fallen by an average of about
0.25 percentage points in months when the participation rate falls 0.3 percentage
points. We recently explored trends in labor force participation (see here and
here), and concluded that the remaining margins of cyclical slack in the near-term
are largely being offset by structural forces weighing on the participation rate. As
such, we expect the participation rate to remain relatively stable in the near term
and the unemployment rate to continue to fall meaningfully further below 4%. In
our forecast, we project the unemployment rate to fall to 3.4% by year-end, which
should result in more noticeable wage pressures as the labor market tightens
well beyond full employment. A more significant overshoot of full employment
and pickup in wage gains support our expectation that the Fed will raise rates
four times in total this year. As this data comes to fruition, we expect the Fed to
converge to our view in the coming months.

TALK's poor FCF performance to date is due to its own mistakes but also because
its main rivals are much bigger and better armed (BT, Sky and Virgin Media together
serve c.80% of the market; TALK's retail share is just c.13%). Even if TALK stops
stumbling, we believe BT, Sky and Virgin Media have not finished making its life
ever more difficult. Separately, if only because of its several profit warnings to
date, we believe TALK must add consistency to its disclosure and it must ensure
its guidance on FCF drivers is reliable. Lastly, TALK, like CityFibre, probably
underestimates FTTP build costs and overestimates likely FTTP take-up/returns.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Tesla reported in its 10-K that 17% of its revenue in 2017 was derived from China. We believe this figure likely includes revenues from Hong Kong (a free-trade zone with steep auto registration taxes that are occasionally lowered for EVs), which accounted for ~4% of global Model S/X deliveries in 2017. Accordingly, we suspect the mainland China exposure for Tesla in ’17 was more like 10-12% of total co. revenue. And, without a joint venture plant in China, any vehicles Tesla sells in China are imported from the US. The tariff will add an extra premium on top of a vehicle price that was already ahead of the base US price, related to transport costs and duties. For instance, a base Model S 100D in the US costs $94k; the same vehicle in China today costs CNY 931k (or ~$148k), and that’s before the added tariff. And while these steep import tariffs are part of the upper-end luxury market (and in some respects add to the prestige factor for luxury cars), for lower-luxury vehicles than the Model 3 a 50% premium would be significant. While news reports from late last year indicated Tesla is looking to establish vehicle manufacturing in China (albeit they would like to avoid a JV partner), which would avoid many of these duties, for now its Chinese-sold vehicles will be at a disadvantage.
